This community has been created for sharing evidence, knowledge, learnings, and updates about research and implementation of simplified approaches, specifically those focused on uniting treatment of severe and moderate acute malnutrition.

paragraphs.text: Simplified approaches can refer to a range of modifications to the standard Community-based Management of Acute Malnutrition (CMAM) model, including the treatment of acute malnutrition as one continuum, with a common approach to detection and treatment of both severe (SAM) and moderate (MAM) acute malnutrition in one programme.Visit the introductory overview page herefor more about what simplified approaches are, and why they may be beneficial in certain contexts.

This Community of Practice is a space for you to share your experiences, and to find out more about how others are learning from innovative adaptations to protocols across multiple contexts. There are currently no WHO guidelines on simplified approaches but this is a dynamic area of research to inform future efforts. This is a place to consider the current evidence, and what adaptations might work where you are, given context-specific barriers to coverage and cost-effectiveness, and coordinate with other implementing organisations regarding pilots, research and national-level discussions.
What do we mean by simplified approaches? Why are they needed and where have they been implemented so far?
What are the various options that could be considered for implementation in different contexts?
What has already been tested, where, and what were the findings?
A set of simple tools developed by the International Rescue Committee, UNICEF and other partners, for the CHW treatment of wasting in the context of COVID-19.
A set of simple tools developed by the International Rescue Committee for low-literate community health workers.
Policy-reviews; body composition outcomes of treating MAM with RUTF; and how the reduced dosage of RUTF for SAM was calculated
Outstanding questions and answers from implementers
Examples from both research and operational pilots

In addition to these examples, UNICEF is supporting the operational pilots of simplified approaches for the treatment of acute malnutrition across West and Central Africa. They are working with Ministries of Health to develop their own variations of simplified approaches, find implementing partners, and access useful resources, such as training documents and protocol outlines.Contact Sophie Woodheadfor more information.

WebinarOn 28 February 2023, the Simplified Approaches Working Group, together with the GNC Technical Alliance, hosted the webinar“Introducing Global Training Toolkit on Simplified Approaches for the Detection and Treatment of Child Wasting; Chapter 1: Family MUAC”. Find recordinghere.

The World Health Organization, the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, the United Nations Children’s Fund, and the World Food Programme releaseda recommendation on simplified approaches for the treatment of child wastingfollowing a technical consultation in Geneva, 26–27 March 2019.
Got a question? Get in touch oninfo@acutemalnutrition.org

Between 2015 and 2020, The State of Acute Malnutrition was supported by theNo Wasted LivesCoalition, an interagency effort between Action Against Hunger, the Children’s Investment Fund Foundation, the European Commission Directorate-General for Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection (ECHO), the innocent foundation, the International Rescue Committee (IRC), UNICEF, and World Food Programme (WFP). The CMAM 2.0: Reinventing Community Management of Acute Malnutrition grant supported by the Children’s Investment Fund Foundation that financed the No Wasted Lives initiative, is now closed.
